This newfound drive can be heard in singles such as “LesAlpx”, a mind-melting track that climbs breathlessly towards its summit with a pounding bass beat and high, whistling chirps that punctuate the tension. It’s an insight into his brilliant mind and – such is the sheer variety of the album – a way to inspire one’s own imagination. (RO)2750 24) Stormzy – Heavy is the HeadThere are three themes that run through the record: his defiance in the face of doubt the pressure of high expectations and his efforts to lift others up as his success continues to grow. He reminds himself constantly of who he is beneath the gloss that fame has brought: he’s “Rachael’s Little Brother”, “Big Michael”, a guy who likes to watch Avengers and Game of Thrones. All of his best traits are present and correct: sincerity, a smooth flow and forensic-like analysis of societal ills, laced with pathos and humour. The lasting impression is of an artist whose only way is up. (RO)A blunt, bold album on which Hackman’s beatific voice sits atop methodically messy instrumentals. Songs such as “All Night” are so candidly carnal it feels inappropriate to listen to them in public notes of riot grrrl, pop and rock come together throughout the record to create something that is, at times, quite striking. (AP)2950 22) Solange – When I Get HomeThe decade’s second great Solange album churns several deformed, jazzy aesthetics – including Brainfeeder’s gloopy electro-funk and the concoctions of DJ Screw – into a lustrous cloud of R&ampB. The result hints at Seventies soul voyagers like Stevie Wonder yet retains its future-shock, celebrating Houston futurism without pandering to fans of its explicitly political predecessor. (JM)For her fifth studio album, Cate Le Bon went to live in a secluded cottage in the Lake District, where she sang to an empty house and took lessons in wood-carving. Yet her compositions on Reward are lush, warm and whimsical opener “Miami” is resplendent with stately horns and percussion that reminds you of childhood. There’s a fantastic sense of space, too, spun from diaphanous arrangements such as “The Light”, where she meanders delightfully from a clear, lilting call to a deep vocal rumble. It’s an album by an artist intent on readdressing her relationship with her own existence. (RO)Fender drew plenty of early comparisons to Bruce Springsteen – on Hypersonic Missiles they’re entirely warranted, as much for the instrumentation as the lyricism and his vignettes of working-class struggle. There are sax solos (more than one), and pounding rhythms that make you want to jump in a car and drive down a highway at sunset, and blistering electric guitars next to classic troubadour acoustics. He has Springsteen’s rousing holler, and the early indications of someone who could be the voice of a generation – not because he wants to be, but because he sees things and understands. (RO)Swift’s sixth album Reputation was camp and melodramatic, killing off “the old Taylor” and waging war on anyone and everyone who dared to criticise her. It was sincerity veiled as self-parody, insecurity veiled as breeziness – and all the better for that uneasy paradox. But Lover, her new, seventh album, feels like a partial resurrection of the Swift of old: moony romance and earnest earworms abound. It’s the sound of a singer excited to be earnest again. Taylor Swift is dead. Long live Taylor Swift. (AP)The record is an introspective mix of psychey soul, blues, rock and funk, which skips and strolls and swaggers through its 13 tracks – but it is not simply an exercise in nostalgia. Its influences  decades Gil Scott-Heron, Fela Kuti, Kendrick Lamar and Bobby Womack are all recalled. “I’m not going to have an alter ego, or becomes Sasha Fierce or Ziggy Stardust,” says Kiwanuka. “I can just be Michael Kiwanuka.” With an album this good, it’s hard to argue with that. (AP)On his sixth album, Kano’s powers of observation are at their peak. Home has always been at the heart of his music, so he maintains the close-quarters perspective of his 2005 debut Home Sweet Home the swaggering confidence of that record, though, is replaced by a more thoughtful gravitas. He’s an elder statesman of grime, and you can almost see his furrowed brow and shake of his head on “Trouble”, while the frenetic “Class of Deja”, starring fellow veterans D Double E and Ghetts, reminds the listener how he lit the path for future generations. (RO)3550 16) Hot Chip – A Bath Full of EcstasyLyrically, the band offer up some of their most poignant phrases to date on this – their seventh and best record. Second single “Hungry Child”, a trance-y floor-filler, contains the plaintive, “Dreaming never felt so bad Lonely never felt so wrong before” while, over the shuffling beats of “Echo”, Alexis Taylor sings of leaving your regrets behind while seeming to understand the effort required to achieve this. For all its glimmering synths and the robotic pathos of Taylor’s idiosyncratic vocals, this is a record with both heart and soul. (RO)3650 15) MUNA – Saves the WorldSaves the World should see MUNA joining the ranks of those who have brazenly borrowed their sound. Lead single “Number One Fan” banishes intrusive thoughts – “Nobody likes me and I’m gonna die” – just in time for a lavish, self-celebratory chorus, one part earnest, one part tongue-in-cheek. Elsewhere, they are downright defeatist, laments the inevitable pull back to a recent ex (“Stayaway”) or reflecting on a lover’s similarity to an adulterous father (“Taken”). “Hands Off”, meanwhile, toys with temptation before slamming the door shut. It is fierce and forthright. (AP)Fans have already drawn comparisons between We Are Not Your Kind and Slipknot’s seminal 2001 album Iowa. While the latter was even heavier (it would be difficult if not impossible to outdo), the sheer ambition on We Are Not Your Kind is just as staggering. If anything, the dynamic created by placing a bigger emphasis on melody allows you to consider everything without being engulfed by noise. Critics may question how relevant Slipknot are in 2019. The pummelling force of We Are Not Your Kind should be enough to silence them – this may be one of the band’s most personal records, but the rage they capture is universally felt. (RO)Each song is titled after a black woman Rapsody admires: Serena Williams, Sojourner Truth, Maya Angelou, Aaliyah, Oprah Winfrey… and for each one she explores these women’s traits, successes and strife. As on Laila’s Wisdom, Eve conveys Rapsody’s natural feel for funk – “Michelle” (Obama) bounces in on a jaunty piano riff – but other tracks, such as “Afeni”, are pure soul. Nina Simone said an artist’s duty, “as far as I’m concerned, is to reflect the times”. This is precisely what Rapsody has done, in the most resonant way possible. (RO)There’s a deeper sense of personal connection to anchor Julia Jacklin’s lyrical and melodic smarts. That snare drum on “Pressure to Party” keeps a relentless, nerve-snapping pulse throughout, while “Don’t Know How to Keep Loving You” nails a depth of intimacy while acknowledging relationship ennui. Grunge-rinsed, feminist-flipped, upcycled Fifties guitar an’ all: Crushing is a triumph. (HB)Philippakis’s voice is shrouded in the smoke from society’s wreckage. Lead single “Exits”, six scintillating minutes of Eighties “sledgehammer” pop that lumbers into view like a heavy artillery vehicle covered in sequins, concerns the one percenters building underground cities to escape global warming. “Syrups” has Yannis howling a passionate post-apocalyptic vision of robot invasions and sand-clogged towns over a corroded Gorillaz dub that builds to a motoric charge as global panic sets in. An inspired album of scorched earth music. (MB)A talented pianist as well as a rapper and singer, Dave often spits over discordant chords to amplify the urgency of his chosen subject, or else raps in gruff, assertive tones across an emotional sequence that complements his stoic intensity. On “Environment”, he talks about the conflict between what people see of his apparently glamorous life, and the reality behind the scenes where the blood and sweat is drawn out of him. He’s put everything into this album. (RO)Weyes Blood, whose real name is Natalie Mering, accompanies her instrumental idiosyncrasies with strong, luscious melodies and unfussy lyrics. “No one’s ever gonna give you a trophy for all the pain and the things you’ve been through,” she sings on “Mirror Forever”. “No one knows but you.”And then there’s that voice – at once warm and haunting, controlled and untethered. It’s no wonder she’s lent it to the likes of Perfume Genius, Drugdealer and Ariel Pink: it adds a touch of profundity to everything it meets. (AP)The warm splashes of piano that washed over that song also break through the anxious rattle of dance beats on the album’s eponymous opener, the singer so regularly reviewed as “vaporous” promises to “leave the ether, assume form” and “be touchable, be reachable”. His own sharpest critic, he winks at the journalists who’ve called him glacial as he drops from remote, icy falsetto into a richly grained, deeper tone to ask: “Doesn’t it seem much warmer?” (HB)Following the traumatised chaos of 2016’s Skeleton Tree, Ghosteen is a warm cloud of ambient solace – a sonic evocation of the communion he has experienced through his newly porous relationship with his audience. He sounds buoyed, not weakened, by exposing his wounds. (HB)4550 6) Tyler, the Creator – IGORThe production here is superb. Tyler has never been one for traditional song structure, but on IGOR, which is undoubtedly a break-up album, he’s like the Minotaur – luring you through a maze that twists and turns around seemingly impossible corners, drawing you into the thrilling unknown. Its lack of resolution at the close – surely the most torturous element of a great love lost – makes it all the more powerful. (RO)The indie-rock band’s second album in the space of five months (the first being UFOF), was described as the “earth twin” and, indeed, they sound utterly grounded – to each other, and to their surroundings in the arid Chihuahuan Desert of Texas, near the Mexico border. In contrast to her fragile performance on UFOF, here Adrianne Lenker sings in lusty whoops and calls on “Forgotten Eyes”, while “Not”, the record’s dark, brooding soul, caterwauls with feedback screeches and a merciless, two-minute guitar solo that leaves you simultaneously devastated and enthralled. (RO)Bruce Springsteen seems to have told almost every tale in the grand old storybook of American mythologies, except perhaps one: a wide-eyed Californian dreamer finds the Golden State turns sour and flees back east, to some romantic speck of a town, to pine and rehabilitate. It’s the classic pop plotline of Bacharach and David’s “Do You Know the Way to San Jose?”, and it’s a tale Springsteen taps repeatedly here, on his sumptuous, cinematic 19th album, which is nothing short of a late-period masterpiece. (MB)Few albums in 2019 have been as eclectic, or with as singular a vision, as Simz’s GREY Area. She flips between two tones: formidable and reflective. On tracks such as “Offence” and “Boss” she drips with venom delivering lines in a low, deadly buzz over killer bass hooks and punk distortion. On “Selfish” and “Flowers” she’s softer – allowing herself to be vulnerable because she knows she doesn’t have to ditch all sentiment to compete with her male peers. She’s better because she embraces every facet of herself, and offers it to the listener in as clear a statement as possible. (RO)Lana Del Rey has always been obsessed with the past. Hers is a sound rooted in nostalgia, a paean to everything she was born too late to live through: old Hollywood, Sinatra, beat poetry, Sylvia Plath and Fifties Americana. At her best, she mines something fresh from it all. At her worst, she wallows in it. Her new album Norman F**king Rockwell!, named after a 20th-century American artist, does both. (AP)When Aldous Harding performed in London this month, an enamoured fan cried out that they loved her. “I appreciate that,” she replied softly. “But, I’m busy.” The response is Harding to a T – wry, weird, introspective, focused. Her spectacular, singular third album, Designer, is all of those things. Taking the left-field folk that made her name and splashing post-psych pop and jittery orchestral flourishes onto the canvas, the New Zealander harbours secrets while beckoning you in. Stormzy added that criticism of Markle is “rubbish” and there is “nothing credible” about people’s negative views against her.In the same interview, the rapper recalled the backlash to his comments about Britain being racist.“I said Britain’s racist, not a risky thing to say,” he said, “but Brits are super in denial… If you hear them talk about her.”The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Campaigners welcome ban but say new gambling act is needed to protect vulnerable puntersGambling customers will no longer be able to use their credit cards to place bets online in a major shake-up of industry regulations.The Gambling Commission has announced that anyone who wants to bet online from 14 April will have to use either a debit card or cash deposited into an account.The ban on credit cards will affect all gambling, with the exception of the National Lottery, following efforts by the government to tackle problem gambling and protect vulnerable customers.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Credit card gambling can lead to significant financial harm,” Neil McArthur, the commission’s chief executive, said.“The ban that we have announced today should minimise the risks of harm to consumers from gambling with money they do not have.”Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Puppeteers from Vision Mechanic rehearsing with Scotland's largest puppet, a ten-metre tall sea goddess called Storm, in the grounds of the Museum of Flight, East Lothian. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Head of state announces ‘period of transition’, with Duke and Duchess of Sussex living in Canada and UKThe Queen&nbsphas backed the Duke and Duchess of Sussex following a crisis summit about their future roles, saying the royal family “respect and understand” their desire to step back as senior royals.The head of state announced there would be a “period of transition” which will see Prince Harry and Meghan&nbspliving in Canada and the UK.In a statement issued by Buckingham Palace, the Queen said: “Today my family had very constructive discussions on the future of my grandson and his family.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“My family and I are entirely supportive of Harry and Meghan’s desire to create a new life as a young family.“Although we would have preferred them to remain full-time working members of the royal family, we respect and understand their wish to live a more independent life as a family while remaining a valued part of my family.”Created with Sketch.Everything that led to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle stepping down Show all 21Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.She continued: “Harry and Meghan have made clear that they do not want to be reliant on public funds in their new lives.“It has therefore been agreed that there will be a period of transition in which the Sussexes will spend time in Canada and the UK.“These are complex matters for my family to resolve, and there is some more work to be done, but I have asked for final decisions to be reached in the coming days.”The Queen was joined at Sandringham&nbspby the Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge for the talks with Harry.It is unusual for the Queen to issue a statement in her own name. Such statements are typically deployed when paying condolences after the death of a foreign head of state, or expressing sympathies after a natural disaster or terror attack.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe monarch did not use the formal titles of the couple – the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Harry and Meghan announced on Wednesday they wanted to step back as senior royals and be financially independent.The couple&nbspmade the shock announcement without telling the Queen or other senior royals first, with the mood at the palace reported to be one of disappointment.The palace later poured cold water on the announcement by saying the couple’s plans were not finalised and discussions remained “at an early stage”.“We understand their desire to take a different approach, but these are complicated issues that will take time to work through,” a spokesperson for the palace said.Meghan returned to Canada to be with eight-month-old son Archie after the couple’s announcement and it is thought she joined the discussions at Sandringham&nbspby phone.There were also reports the couples’ two pet dogs had remained in Canada after Harry and Meghan travelled there in November for a six-week break in November,&nbspprompting speculation the couple plan to set up their permanent home in North America.Their decision to distance themselves from the royal family drew mixed reactions from the British public.Many expressed sympathy For Harry and Meghan but said they should not receive taxpayer-funded security if they do not perform public duties.​A poll for the&nbspDaily Mail&nbspfound 76 per cent of the British public believe Harry and Meghan&nbspshould sacrifice their politan Police protection after they step back. contraction could be as much as 4 per cent, according to a survey of senior directors.The research, based on 250 senior executives at medium-large sized businesses across the UK, also revealed that well over a third (37 per cent) also expect to see a global recession or international global crisis in 2020.The survey by trade finance provider Stenn found that almost two-thirds of firms ranked story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Move comes after Boris Johnson said agreement should be scrapped and replaced with a better 'Trump deal'The Iran nuclear deal is in fresh trouble after the UK and other EU powers triggered a 'dispute mechanism’ in protest at Tehran’s breaches of the agreement.The move brings the EU a step closer to reimposing sanctions on Iran if the row cannot be resolved and is brought back to the United Nations security council. Iran's foreign ministry spokesman said Tehran would give a firm and serious response to the move.&nbspBut the triggering of the dispute mechanism also could mark&nbspa potential setback in Iran's efforts to separate Europe from the US, which has been pressuring leaders in western capitals to join in its maximum pressure campaign against the Iranian regime.&nbsp&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlines“It definitely takes the deal into a new phase, said&nbspEllie&nbspGeranmayeh, a scholar at the European Council on Foreign Relations. I’s going to be a chapter that the Europeans are going to own, both the process and the outcome.Europeans have been murmuring about the possibility of invoking the dispute mechanism&nbspcame soon after Boris Johnson said the agreement should be scrapped and replaced with a better “Trump deal”, which the US president would negotiate.The row has escalated after Iran has suspended all limits on its production of enriched uranium, in a response to the assassination of Qassem Soleimani.It marked a further step back from its commitments under the 2015 accord, because the uranium can be used to make nuclear weapons as well as reactor fuel.&nbspThe Iran plane crash is a chance for a thaw, but not with Boris as PMGerman foreign minister Heiko&nbspMaas&nbspsaid the Europeans could no longer leave the increasing Iranian violations of the nuclear agreement unanswered.Our goal is clear, he said in a statement. We want to preserve the agreement and reach a diplomatic solution within its framework. We will tackle this together with all partners to the deal. We call on Iran to participate constructively in the negotiation process that is now beginning.Dominic Raab, the foreign secretary issued a joint statement with the foreign ministers of France and Germany, known collectively as the ‘E3’.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThey have tried, with Russia and China, to keep the agreement alive ever since&nbspDonald Trump&nbsppulled the US out in 2018, long before the latest crisis in the Gulf.But anger has grown in Iran over crippling US sanctions which have caused its oil exports to collapse and the value of its currency to plummet, resulting in soaring inflation.Iran contends that by largely abiding by US sanctions, European powers have been complicit in the US campaign to pressure the country. But European officials argue they have little control over the private businesses that decline to do commerce with Iran for fear of triggering American reprisals.The move by the E3 had been long anticipated, especially after Iran's most recent downgrading of its commitment to the terms of the deal. But experts fear it could trigger a fresh round of escalation between Iran and the west.&nbspThere's a&nbspbackdrop of military escalation happening between the US&nbspand Iran, said Ms Geranmayeh. The Iranians&nbsphave left open the door for a diplomatic effort. If they&nbspfeel that the Europeans in addition to the Americans are cornering them and it might encourage them to expand the nuclear programme further.In their joint statement, the three EU countries stressed they wanted to save the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPoA) and remained “fully committed” to it.Created with Sketch.Protests in Iran over downing of plane and tensions with the West Show all 23Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.123 Anti-government protest at Amirkabir UniversityIranian police officers take position while protesters gather in front of Amir Kabir University223 Anti-government protest at Amirkabir UniversityIranians demonstrate following a tribute for the victims of the Ukraine Boeing 737 crash in front of the Amirkabir University in the capital Tehran323 Anti-government protest at Amirkabir UniversityIranian police dispersed students chanting radical slogans during a gathering in Tehran to honour the 176 people killed when an airliner was mistakenly shot down423 Anti-government protest at Amirkabir University - title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. They aren’t financially independent now — they get £.- million from the Prince Of Wales and about five per cent from the Sovereign Grant.Harry is reasonably wealthy but not necessarily in cash flow. The sums he inherited from his mother and great grandmother have been invested.Meghan has some means but to live the sort of lestyle they are used to takes a lot of money.It is conceivable Charles could cut the money he gives to Harry —he gives him any at all. Being a dad, he probably will.But there are tax implications — particularlythere are handouts.Security has also to be considered. Harry is a prince of the United Kingdom, his grandmother head of state and father heir.The atmosphere at the meeting will be, up to a point, heated. But people won’t lose their tempers.The Queen is pragmatic. She understands problems people have but Harry will be fully aware of her displeasure. To go off half-cocked as he and Meghan did is unacceptable.The question is how dare they do that. She signed up for this. So what’s changed their minds I’d love to be a fly on the wall of the events in that meeting . . . provided no one has a fly swat!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen must be firm harry meghan
story: So we hope that Meghan and Harry can come to a suitable arrangement with the rest of the royals.But what’s clear is the couple must not receive a penny from the state.British taxpayers fund the Royal Family to strengthen our nation’s soft power, and to support vital charities.If Meghan and Harry can’t be bothered with the legwork, then it goes without saying they must give up the whopping perks which come with it.As for security, claims that to stay safe the pair need cash from daddy just won’t wash. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are rich beyond the wildest dreams of almost everyone in the UK.They are more than capable of paying for a few bodyguards. Andthey find themselves struggling, they could always cut down on the private jets.The Queen, Charles and Wills must be firm: the Sussexes have made their bed. Now they’ve got to lie in it.A CIVILISED nation treats its veterans with respect.Which is why we were delighted when Boris Johnson won the election on a manesto promising to end witch hunt prosecutions against ageing former soldiers who served in Northern Ireland.But to get Stormont up and running, the Prime Minister has brokered a deal with Sinn Fein which risks opening up new probes into thousands of Troubles veterans. This would be morally indefensible and politically mad.Yes, a working government in Northern Ireland would be a good thing. But the safety and wellbeing of our elderly veterans is too big a price tag.And given Boris won the election by being a proud patriot, it makes political sense for him to stand by the armed forces through thick and thin.If the PM is to hold the hard-earned trust of new Conservative voters, he must never give way to those who would put our old soldiers in the dock.IT would be fair to assume that anyone injecting plastic into someone’s face should have some qualications to do so.But a strange loophole in the law means that though Botox is classied as a medicine in Britain, dermal fillers aren’t covered by any regulation.A staggering  per cent of facial fillers are performed by people with no medical training, often in unsanitary conditions — with devastating results.Which is why The Sun’s Fabulous brand is launching the Had Our Fill campaign, urging for a crackdown on unregulated cosmetic fillers, and raising awareness to help women make safer, more informed choices.We’ve had our fill of dodgy fillers. title: sainsburys shoppers baffled bargain
story: A number of baked goods in the reduced section at the Sainsburys in Coldhams common in Cambridge were branded as absolute steals.One shopper said: My partner and I had walked to Sainsbury’s at around pm to buy some aubergines for dinner. Unfortunately there weren’t any when we arrived so we walked round to the bakery to see what reduced offers there were.At first I was excited to see chocolate croissants reduced, but then I realised it was only by p.I then noticed another item had also been reduced by this amount.We pointed it out to the lady working at the bakery and she laughed and said it was a mistake.He also said that he felt a bit let down that Sainburys was trying to fool customers into thinking they were getting a good deal on something.He added: To be fair, I think they changed it after we saw them.However the shop recently did a good deed when a woman discovered two £ Sainsburys gt cards from .Beverly Hardy found her nans vouchers in a suitcase and the store agreed to let her use them.The -year-old posted a picture of them on the Sainsbury’s Facebook feed and the supermarket giant replied to say it would replace them. She said: “I just put it out there for a bit of history. I wasn’t expecting anything.”Her grandmother Mabel Homan died aged  in .The vouchers had been issued the previous December by the Henry Smith Charity, which gives money to the less well-off.Beverly, of Ascot, Berks, and dad Raymond Homan, , discovered them in an envelope in a suitcase untouched for decades.

title: human snake skin condition
story: The youngster, known only as Jagannath, has have a bath every hour and to cover himself in moisturiser every three hours to relieve his painful symptoms.Shocking photos of the young boy, from the Ganjam district of eastern India, show his skin completely dried out and flaky, stretched over his body like scales.His skin has become so tight that he is often left unable to walk properly, and needs a stick to help him stretch out his limbs.Sadly, there is no cure for Jagannaths condition - and his father, Prabhakar Pradhan, who works as a labourer in a paddy field, can not afford the cost of his sons treatment.He said: My son has suffered this disease since childhood, and there is no cure for it.I do not have enough money to take him for a treatment and my heart breaks seeing him suffer with this cursed disease every day.A dermatologist in the Indian district, who did not wish to be identied, said: This disease is not treatable, although some doctors say there is a cure.Dr Rakhesh, senior consultant dermatologist at Aster MIMS hospital in Kerala, India, said lamellar ichthyosis is one of the rarest congenital skin conditions.There is currently no cure, but the condition can be treated with creams and some medications to prevent complications and improve quality of le.

title: chloe ayling kidnap reduced sentence
story: Lukasz Herba, , was convicted last year for bundling terried Chloe into a holdall and driving her to an isolated farmhouse with his brother Michal.The Brit based pair claim they abducted the model as part of a publicity stunt and both are serving long term jail sentences in Italy where they snatched her.But now an Appeal Court has ruled Lukasz should have almost five years taken off his sentence because he acted compassionately during the kidnap in Milan in July .In its judgement the court noted he acted out of love adding that he had not abandoned her in an isolated area when he released her but driven her to the British consulate in Milan.The unusual mitigating circumstances mean that he will now serve  years and one month instead of the  years and nine months he was originally given.Lukasz was sentenced in  after former Big Brother star Chloe, , described how she had been kidnapped in Milan when she turned up for a bogus photoshoot.Mum of one Chloe, from Coulsdon, south west London, has insisted it was not a publicity stunt despite eyebrows being raised by sceptics.The brothers claimed she was in on the plot which would have seen her auctioned as a sex slave to a shadowy internet group called Black Death unless a £, ransom was paid.Last month she confessed to a threesome with Dan Osborne and Natalia Nunn and she has also dated former Premier League footballer Jermaine Pennant.In December Polish born Michal, , was given  years for his part in the kidnap after being extradited from Oldbury, West Midlands, where he loved with his brother.Chloe appeared at his trial last summer via video link and broke down in tears as he relieved her traumatic ordeal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen mistake reign harry meghan demands
story: The public will be repulsedthese two quitters continue to make a penny from them — and yes, that includes the ancient Duchy of Cornwall, which Prince Charles only inherited as the monarch’s eldest son.But that’s only the start. title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Daily Mail piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. It is also b*****ks.When the couple first got together, the coverage was gushing across the board.It was only when Meghan and Harry started on their ious virtue-signalling cru-sades — such as jetting around to lecture on climate change — that people’s backs went up.That the couple had already been beefing with the Press probably didn’t help either.In , way before Meghan became a figure in our culture wars, Harry issued a remarkable statement rebuking journalists for the “racial undertones” of their pieces.That these privileged royals, kept in the lap of luxury at taxpayers’ expense, began to develop a deep-seated victim complex only heightened the resentment towards them.Last year, Meghan told ITV public le was a “struggle” and she was shocked that “not many people have askedI’m OK”. title: philippines taal volcano ash evacuation
story: Scientists warned of a worse eruption to come today as the peak was rocked by  earthquakes and fresh fissures spewed boiling magma half a mile high.Tens of thousands of people have already fled the danger zone, only  miles south of capital Manila with a population of million.Yesterday a giant column of smoke was lit up by spectacular lightning flashes inside the dark cloud.Today shocking photos reveal the devastation around Lake Taal, where homes, forests and abandoned resorts are coated in a thick layer of ash.Schools and offices in Manila were shut because of the dangerous dust, and hundreds of flights have been grounded at the countrys main airport leaving , people stranded.And the eruption continued as fountains of red-hot lava were flung at least minto the sky amid the constant rumbling of tremors.More than  quakes over eight hours today were caused by molten rock rising to the surface - a possible indicator of imminent catastrophe, according to the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology.The volcano-monitoring agency raised the danger level around Taal three notches to Level  - indicating an imminent hazardous eruption.Level , the highest, means a hazardous eruption is underway and could affect a larger area.Renato Solidum, who heads the institute, said: The speed in the rise of magma is importantwhen the volcano will have a strong eruption andit will slow down and freeze.As of now, we dont see activities slowing down and the earthquakes still continue.He warned evacuees not toto their villages yet or they risk being incinerated by pyroclastic flow, an avalanche of super-heated debris that can gush down the volcano.The countrys disaster-response agency counted more than , evacuees in Batangas and nearby Cavite provinces who are being housed in  shelters.Officials expect that number to swell.Villages living on the same island as ,ft Mount Taal have been moved, but scientists have called for a total evacuation of half a million people within  miles of the volcano.Wilson Maralit, Mayor of Balete on the shore of Taal Lake, told DZMM radio, called for extra troops and police to help.He said: “Our people are panicking due to the volcano because they want to save their livelihood, their pigs and herds of cows.“We’re trying to stop them from ing and warning that the volcano can explode again any time and hit them.”Between  and , it experienced  eruptions, six of which caused deaths.A period of activity in  continued for more than half a year and covered six towns with ash.A violent eruption in  killed more than , people.Local resident Irene de Claro said she was worried about her dad, who stayed behind in the village of Agoncillo.She said: “We don’t know what happened to our house because the ash was up to our knees, it was very dark and the ground was constantly shaking when we left.“Most likely there’s nothing for us toto. Were back to zero.”So far the eruption has not directly killed anyone - although a lorry driver died skidding on ash.At least six people have been taken to hospital in Tagaytay city with breathing problems.Taals last disastrous eruption, in , killed hundreds of people.It is the second-most active of about two dozen volcanoes in the Philippines, which lies along the Pacic Ring of Fire where most of the worlds seismic activity occurs.In  a long-dormant volcano, Mount Pinatubo, blew its top north of Manila in one of the biggest eruptions of the th century, killing hundreds of people.The exact cause of volcanic lightning - which typically occurs at the start of an eruption - long has been debated among scientists, as the phenomenon is more dficult to study than the lightning that’s associated with thunderstorms.In , however, researchers determined volcanic lightning may be a result of both volcanic ash and ice.“One cause is static electricity from particles rubbing together in dense ash clouds near the ground.The other source of lightning happens near the stratosphere, high above the Earths surface, where jockeying ice crystals unleash powerful jolts,” reports Live Science.The earliest recorded observations of volcanic lightning are from Pliny the Younger, describing the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in  AD.There was a most intense darkness rendered more appalling by the fitful gleam of torches at intervals obscured by the transient blaze of lightning, he wrote.The first scientic studies of volcanic lightning were also conducted at Mount Vesuvius by Professor Palmieri who observed the eruptions of , , , and  from the Vesuvius Observatory.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: what weather bomb
story: But what actually is the phenomenon and how is a weather bomb formed A weather bomb is a term used to describe a specic low-pressure system.When storms quickly intensy and pressure rapidly drops in the centre - by millibars in a -hour period - this is known as a weather bomb.The process is also known as explosive cyclogenesis.A weather bomb sees dry air flow into an area of low pressure.As a result, this causes the depression within the storm to rise rapidly and increase its rotation, deepening the pressure and making the storm even more powerful.Weather bombs often peak over a period of a few hours and resulting winds can be strong enough to bring down trees and cause structural damage.The Met Office describes the phenomenon as similar to the way that ice skaters spin faster by drawing their arms in as they rotate.While weather bombs can strike around the world the four most active regions are the North Atlantic, the South Atlantic, the Pacic Northwest and the southwest Pacic.The Met Office describes a weather bomb as: Rapid acceleration of air caused by the jet stream high up in the atmosphere can remove air from the column, reducing its weight so causing pressure to fall at sea level.This in turn sucks in air which converges from surrounding regions resulting in faster and faster rotation of the circulation,  in the same way that ice skaters spin faster by drawing their arms in. The resulting winds peak over a period of a few hours and can be strong enough to bring down trees and cause structural damage. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast storm brendan wind travel
story: Further weather warnings have been issued for this afternoon and evening, with torrential rain and strong winds forecast across most of the country.The Met Office has yellow warnings for wind covering much of the UK throughout Tuesday.This will be accompanied by heavy rain, the worst of which is likely to be in southern England between pm today and am tomorrow.Travel across the UK has already been disrupted, with flights, trains and ferry services delayed or cancelled.The high winds forced airlines to ert flights scheduled to land at Gatwick Airport.Seven flights to Gatwick Airport have been erted to other locations across the UK so far, after gales in excess of mph struck the area last night.Gatwick Airport said two Wizz Air flights, four easyJet services and one Norwegian Air flight were erted.One easyJet flight from Edinburgh was forced to land at Birmingham.In Wales, more than , properties were left without power after a tree fell onto a power line in Bontnewydd, Gwynedd.The strongest gust recorded during Storm Brendan was mph in South Uist in the Western Isles of Scotland, with winds of more than mph also recorded in Wales and the Isle Of Scilly.The Met Office has issued four weather warnings across the UK including two for strong winds in north western Scotland and most of England and Wales.There is also a warning for snow and ice across central Scotland and the highlands.Met Office spokesman Oli Claydon said that northern and western Scotland will continue to be hit with high winds of mph to mph from Storm Brendon.However, a new low pressure trains and ferries.He added: We are looking at gusts of mph to mph with exposed coasts and the tops of hills seeing mph and maybe even up to mph.With that theres also going to be some rain, making conditions quite unpleasant.Its certainly going to be unpleasant driving conditions and could lead to disruption across many travel networks.On Monday, more than  homes were blacked out after electricity failures near Falmouth and Truro in Cornwall as the winds began bringing trees down across cables.In the Western Isles, all schools in Uist and Barra are closed and all bus services on the islands have also been cancelled.Several Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services are affected, with some services cancelled due to adverse weather and others disrupted.Northlink Ferries also told passengers there may be disruption on services to Orkney and Shetland.Gales of up to mph affected railways across the country on Monday, while drivers were advised to take extra care on the roads.After plaguing parts of Ireland, causing thousands of homes and businesses to lose power, the storm brought high winds to parts of England and Scotland.Seven flood warnings and  alerts issued by the Environment Agency remained in place on Tuesday morning.The Met Office has also issued a yellow warning of rain to cover the South East today, where heavy rain is expected to cause disruption and the flooding of a few homes and businesses is likely.Although the rest of the week looks unsettled, conditions are set to be drier and brighter at the weekend.
